unit_title: Ampere's Law: Line Integrals and Magnetic Field Symmetry
subject: AP Physics C: Electricity & Magnetism
expanded_description: This unit introduces Ampere's Law as a powerful method for calculating magnetic fields in symmetric current distributions. Students will master the application of line integrals around Amperian loops, develop intuition for choosing appropriate integration paths, and apply these techniques to solenoids, toroids, and other symmetric configurations where direct integration of Biot-Savart Law would be complex.
learning_objectives: Apply Ampere's Law to calculate magnetic fields in symmetric configurations
Set up and evaluate line integrals around Amperian loops
Determine when Ampere's Law is applicable based on symmetry
Calculate magnetic fields inside and outside current distributions
Analyze the magnetic field of solenoids and toroids using Ampere's Law
Solve problems involving multiple current-carrying regions
prerequisites: Understanding of line integrals and vector calculus
Knowledge of current distributions and symmetry

core_concept.principle: Ampere's Law, Line Integrals, Amperian Loops, Magnetic Field Symmetry, Current Enclosed
core_concept.explanation: Ampere's Law states that the line integral of the magnetic field around any closed path equals μ₀ times the current enclosed by that path. This powerful relationship simplifies magnetic field calculations in symmetric configurations where the field is constant along integration paths, making it particularly useful for solenoids, toroids, and infinite current sheets.

sections.section_title: 1. Ampere's Law Fundamentals and Basic Applications
sections.introduction: This section establishes Ampere's Law as a fundamental relationship in electromagnetism and applies it to basic symmetric current configurations, developing the methodology for choosing appropriate Amperian loops.

key_concept.definition: Ampere's Law, Line Integral, Amperian Loop, Current Enclosed, Right-Hand Rule
key_concept.context: Ampere's Law provides an integral relationship between magnetic fields and the currents that produce them. Unlike the differential Biot-Savart Law, Ampere's Law works with the total field around closed paths, making it particularly powerful for systems with high symmetry where the field magnitude is constant along the integration path.

image.caption: Fundamental concepts of Ampere's Law and Amperian loops

classifications.value: Classification based on current distribution symmetry
characteristics: Solenoids: axial symmetry with uniform field
Toroids: circular symmetry with varying field
classifications.behavior: Different symmetric configurations allow different Amperian loop choices. Straight wires suggest circular loops. Current sheets suggest rectangular loops. Solenoids suggest rectangular loops enclosing multiple turns. Toroids suggest circular loops following the torus. Cylindrical conductors suggest circular loops at different radii. Multiple conductors may require piecewise application.

classifications.note: Ampere's Law is always true, but it's only useful for calculating magnetic fields when the symmetry allows you to determine the field direction and where it's constant along the integration path

principles.statement: Ampere's Law: ∮B·dl = μ₀I_enc where I_enc is current enclosed by the path. Differential Form: ∇ × B = μ₀J. Right-Hand Rule: Curl fingers in integration direction, thumb shows positive current direction. Amperian Loop Selection: Choose path where B is either parallel or perpendicular to dl, and constant magnitude where parallel. Infinite Straight Wire: Choose circular Amperian loop: B(2πr) = μ₀I → B = μ₀I/(2πr). Infinite Current Sheet: Choose rectangular loop straddling sheet: B(2L) = μ₀KL (K = current per unit width) → B = μ₀K/2 each side. Solenoid: Choose rectangular loop with long sides parallel to axis: B_inL = μ₀nLI → B_in = μ₀nI, B_out = 0. Toroid: Choose circular loop inside: B(2πr) = μ₀NI → B = μ₀NI/(2πr). Current Density: For distributed currents, I_enc = ∫J·dA. Limitations: Requires symmetry to extract B from integral. Doesn't account for changing electric fields (need Maxwell's correction). Always True: But only useful for field calculation with symmetry.
principles.application: Calculate magnetic fields using Ampere's Law for symmetric distributions. Choose appropriate Amperian loops based on symmetry. Determine enclosed current for various geometries. Solve for unknown currents from field measurements. Analyze field behavior inside and outside current distributions. Apply to solenoids, toroids, and cylindrical conductors.
principles.example: Infinite wire: circular loop gives B = μ₀I/(2πr). Solenoid: rectangular loop gives B = μ₀nI inside. Current sheet: rectangular loop gives B = μ₀K/2.
principles.analogy: Ampere's Law is like a 'magnetic circulation meter' that measures how much 'current is swirling inside' any closed loop. Choosing the right Amperian loop is like choosing the right 'fishing net' shape to catch the 'magnetic field pattern'. For a straight wire, a 'circular net' perfectly matches the 'circular field lines'. For a solenoid, a 'rectangular net' that goes inside and outside can 'catch' the difference between the 'strong internal field' and 'weak external field'. The 'right-hand rule' tells you which way to 'walk around your net' to count the 'enclosed fish' (currents) properly. The law always works, but you only 'catch useful information' when your 'net shape' matches the 'swimming patterns of the fish'.

worked_examples.title: Infinite Straight Wire Verification
worked_examples.problem: Use Ampere's Law to find the magnetic field at distance r from an infinite straight wire carrying current I, and verify it matches the Biot-Savart result.

step_by_step.explanation: Select circular loop of radius r centered on wire, due to cylindrical symmetry
∮B·dl = B∮dl = B(2πr) since B is constant and parallel to dl everywhere on circle
I_enc = I (entire current enclosed)
B(2πr) = μ₀I
B = μ₀I/(2πr)
Right-hand rule: grasp wire with right hand, thumb in current direction, fingers curl in B direction

worked_examples.final_answer: B = μ₀I/(2πr), identical to Biot-Savart result. Direction is tangential to circles around wire.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Basic Ampere's Law application to infinite straight wire

image.caption: Ampere's Law application to infinite straight wire

worked_examples.title: Current Sheet Magnetic Field
worked_examples.problem: An infinite sheet in the yz-plane carries uniform surface current K = 8.0 A/m in the +y direction. Find the magnetic field on both sides of the sheet.

step_by_step.explanation: Sheet is infinite in yz-plane, current in y-direction. By symmetry, B should be in ±z direction, constant magnitude, opposite directions on each side
Rectangular loop straddling sheet, with sides parallel to z-axis (field direction) and ends perpendicular
∮B·dl = B∥L + 0 + B∥L + 0 = 2B∥L (only sides parallel to B contribute)
I_enc = KL (current per unit length × length)
2B∥L = μ₀KL
Right-hand rule: for current in +y, field is in -z for x > 0 and +z for x < 0

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic field magnitude = 5.03 μT on both sides. Direction: for x > 0, B = -5.03 μT k; for x < 0, B = +5.03 μT k.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Ampere's Law application to infinite current sheet

image.caption: Magnetic field calculation for infinite current sheet

worked_examples.title: Multiple Parallel Wires
worked_examples.problem: Three infinite parallel wires are equally spaced along the x-axis at x = -0.1 m, 0, and +0.1 m. Each carries 5.0 A current in the +z direction. Find the magnetic field at x = 0.15 m using Ampere's Law concepts.

step_by_step.explanation: Ampere's Law alone cannot find field at specific point for multiple wires - need superposition
B_total = B₁ + B₂ + B₃, with each from infinite wire formula

B from wire at x = -0.1 m: distance = 0.25 m, B = μ₀×5/(2π×0.25) = 4.0×10⁻⁶ T, direction? Right-hand rule: at x=0.15, field from left wire points? Current +z, so B circles counterclockwise: at point to right of wire, B points -y

step_by_step.step: Wire at x = 0: distance = 0.15 m, B = μ₀×5/(2π×0.15) = 6.67×10⁻⁶ T. At point to right of wire, B points -y
Wire at x = +0.1 m: distance = 0.05 m, B = μ₀×5/(2π×0.05) = 2.0×10⁻⁵ T. At point to right of wire, B points +y (opposite!)

step_by_step.explanation: B_total = (-4.0 - 6.67 + 20.0)×10⁻⁶ j? Wait, check signs: B from wires at -0.1 and 0: both -y direction. B from wire at +0.1: +y direction. So B_total = (-4.0μ - 6.67μ + 20.0μ)×10⁻⁶ = +9.33×10⁻⁶ T in +y direction

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic field at x = 0.15 m = 9.33 μT in +y direction. Demonstrates superposition with Ampere's Law results for individual wires.

image.caption: Field calculation for multiple parallel wires using superposition

sections.section_title: 2. Advanced Applications: Solenoids, Toroids, and Current Distributions
sections.introduction: This section extends Ampere's Law to more complex symmetric configurations including solenoids, toroids, and current-carrying cylinders, analyzing both internal and external field behavior and exploring the limitations of the method.

key_concept.definition: Solenoid Field, Toroid Field, Current Density, Cylindrical Conductors, Field Continuity
key_concept.context: Ampere's Law reaches its full power when applied to highly symmetric systems like solenoids and toroids, where direct Biot-Savart integration would be extremely complex. For distributed currents in cylindrical conductors, the law reveals how magnetic fields vary with radius and how total current determines the external field behavior.

image.caption: Ampere's Law applications to solenoids, toroids, and current distributions

classifications.value: Classification based on system geometry and current distribution
characteristics: Ideal solenoids: uniform internal field, zero external field
Finite solenoids: end effects and field fringing
Solid cylindrical conductors: radial field dependence
Hollow cylindrical conductors: field exclusion from voids
Multiple coaxial conductors: piecewise field solutions
classifications.behavior: Different symmetric systems exhibit characteristic field patterns. Ideal solenoids have perfectly uniform internal fields. Finite solenoids show field decrease near ends. Toroids completely confine magnetic fields. Solid conductors have linearly increasing internal fields. Hollow conductors have zero field in empty regions. Multiple conductors require region-by-region analysis.

examples.explanation: Calculating magnetic fields inside and outside current-carrying cylinders

classifications.note: For ideal infinite solenoids, the magnetic field outside is exactly zero, not just small - this is a consequence of the high symmetry and uniform current distribution

principles.statement: Ideal Solenoid: Infinite length, tightly wound, uniform current. Choose rectangular Amperian loop with sides parallel and perpendicular to axis. Only side inside contributes: B_inL = μ₀nLI → B_in = μ₀nI, B_out = 0. Finite Solenoid: Approximation: B_center ≈ μ₀nI, B_end ≈ ½μ₀nI. Toroidal Solenoid: N turns, major radius R, minor radius a << R. Choose circular Amperian loop inside: B(2πr) = μ₀NI → B = μ₀NI/(2πr). Outside: B = 0. Solid Cylindrical Conductor: Radius R, uniform current density J = I/(πR²). Inside (r < R): I_enc = I(r²/R²), B(2πr) = μ₀I(r²/R²) → B = (μ₀Ir)/(2πR²). Outside (r > R): B = μ₀I/(2πr). Hollow Cylinder: Inside hollow (r < R_in): B = 0. Between walls: similar to solid. Outside: B = μ₀I/(2πr). Current Density: For non-uniform J, I_enc = ∫J·dA. Field Continuity: B field is continuous across current distributions. No magnetic monopoles: ∮B·dA = 0 always. Limitations: Requires symmetry to be useful. Cannot handle arbitrary current distributions. Doesn't provide field at specific points without symmetry.
principles.application: Calculate magnetic fields in solenoids and toroids. Analyze field distributions in cylindrical conductors. Determine internal and external fields for various current distributions. Solve problems involving multiple conducting regions. Design electromagnetic devices using Ampere's Law principles. Calculate unknown currents from field measurements.
principles.example: Solenoid: n = 1000 turns/m, I = 2 A → B = 2.51 mT inside. Solid cylinder: R = 0.02 m, I = 10 A → B_max = 0.1 mT at surface.
principles.analogy: Advanced Ampere's Law applications are like using 'specialized magnetic telescopes' for different 'celestial current patterns'. A 'solenoid' is like a 'magnetic laser' - it creates a 'perfectly straight, uniform magnetic beam' inside, with 'no magnetic leakage' outside. A 'toroid' is like a 'magnetic race track' - the field goes 'round and round' forever inside the doughnut, but 'can't escape' outside. A 'current-carrying cylinder' is like a 'magnetic onion' - as you go deeper inside, you 'enclose less current', so the field gets weaker, following a 'linear peeling pattern'. The 'Amperian loop' is your 'magnetic measuring tape' that you 'wrap around' each configuration to 'measure how much current is flowing inside' at each 'peel layer'.

image.caption: Advanced applications of Ampere's Law to symmetric systems

worked_examples.title: Solenoid Magnetic Field
worked_examples.problem: An ideal solenoid is 0.4 m long with 800 turns and carries 3.0 A current. Calculate the magnetic field inside the solenoid and explain why the external field is zero.

step_by_step.explanation: For ideal infinite solenoid, choose rectangular loop with one side inside, one outside. Only inside contributes to integral
If B_out ≠ 0, the line integral wouldn't match enclosed current unless B_out has specific form. Symmetry and current cancellation give B_out = 0 exactly
Finite solenoids have small external fields and end effects

worked_examples.final_answer: Magnetic field inside = 7.54 mT. External field is zero for ideal infinite solenoid due to perfect symmetry and current cancellation.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Solenoid field calculation using Ampere's Law

image.caption: Magnetic field calculation for ideal solenoid

worked_examples.title: Solid Cylindrical Conductor
worked_examples.problem: A solid cylindrical conductor of radius 0.02 m carries 50 A current uniformly distributed. Find the magnetic field at (a) r = 0.01 m, (b) r = 0.02 m, and (c) r = 0.04 m from the axis.

step_by_step.explanation: I_enc = Jπr² = I(r²/R²). B(2πr) = μ₀I(r²/R²) → B = (μ₀Ir)/(2πR²)
B = μ₀I/(2πr) (all current enclosed)

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) 0.785 mT at r = 0.01 m, (b) 1.57 mT at surface, (c) 0.0785 mT at r = 0.04 m. Field increases linearly inside, decreases as 1/r outside.

worked_examples.title: Toroidal Solenoid
worked_examples.problem: A toroidal solenoid has 500 turns wound on a core with major radius 0.15 m and minor radius 0.02 m. It carries 2.0 A current. Find the magnetic field at the mean radius and determine the range where the field is approximately uniform.

step_by_step.explanation: B = μ₀NI/(2πr) where r is the radius from toroid axis
Inner radius = 0.13 m, outer radius = 0.17 m. B_inner = μ₀NI/(2π×0.13) = 4.83 mT, B_outer = μ₀NI/(2π×0.17) = 3.69 mT
From inner to outer: (4.83-3.69)/4.19 = 27% variation. For minor radius << major radius, field is more uniform
For ideal toroid, net current enclosed = 0 for loops outside, so B = 0

worked_examples.final_answer: Field at mean radius = 4.19 mT. Field varies from 4.83 mT (inner) to 3.69 mT (outer). Approximately uniform if minor radius << major radius.

image.caption: Magnetic field calculation for toroidal solenoid

worked_examples.title: Coaxial Cable Fields
worked_examples.problem: A coaxial cable has inner conductor radius 0.005 m carrying 10 A current outward, and outer conductor (radius 0.015 m, thickness 0.002 m) carrying return current. Find the magnetic field in all regions.

step_by_step.explanation: Assume uniform current density. I_enc = I(r²/R₁²) = 10(r²/0.000025). B = (μ₀×10×r)/(2π×0.000025) = (μ₀×10×r)/(1.57×10⁻⁴) = (1.257×10⁻⁵×r)/(1.57×10⁻⁴) = 0.08r T (r in meters)
All inner current enclosed: B = μ₀×10/(2πr) = (2×10⁻⁶)/r T

step_by_step.step: Region 3: Inside outer conductor (0.015 < r < 0.017 m)
step_by_step.explanation: I_enc = 10 - I_outer(r). Outer conductor carries -10 A uniformly in area π(0.017²-0.015²) = π(0.000289-0.000225) = 2.01×10⁻⁴ m². Current density J = -10/2.01×10⁻⁴ = -4.98×10⁴ A/m². I_enc = 10 + J×π(r²-0.015²) = 10 - 4.98×10⁴×π(r²-0.000225). B = μ₀I_enc/(2πr)
Net current enclosed = 10 - 10 = 0, so B = 0

worked_examples.final_answer: Field: Inside inner: B ∝ r, max 0.4 mT. Between: B = 2 μT/r. In outer: B decreases to 0. Outside: B = 0. Magnetic field confined to cable interior.

common_misconceptions: Thinking Ampere's Law can find B at a point without symmetry
Believing the Amperian loop must coincide with a field line
Confusing current enclosed with total current in system
Assuming Ampere's Law gives the field directly rather than the circulation
Thinking solenoids always have zero external field regardless of length
Believing Ampere's Law works for any closed path in any situation
Confusing the differential and integral forms of Ampere's Law
summary: This unit has established Ampere's Law as a powerful tool for calculating magnetic fields in symmetric current distributions. Students have mastered the selection of appropriate Amperian loops, evaluation of line integrals, and application to various symmetric systems including straight wires, solenoids, toroids, and cylindrical conductors. The method's strength in handling complex symmetric configurations where Biot-Savart integration would be formidable, combined with its limitations in asymmetric situations, provides a comprehensive understanding of this fundamental relationship in electromagnetism.
